title: 112_hr2504
content:
The Act is titled the "Coltsville National Historical Park Act" and includes definitions for key terms. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

City: Hartford, Connecticut
Commission: Coltsville National Historical Park Advisory Commission
Historic district: Coltsville Historic District
Map: "Coltsville National Historical Park--Proposed Boundary"
Park: Coltsville National Historical Park in Connecticut
Secretary: Secretary of the Interior
State: Connecticut

SEC. 3. COLTSVILLE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. Establishment of "Coltsville National Historical Park" in the State is subject to conditions including acquiring sufficient land, a written agreement for space donation in the East Armory for park facilities. The establishment of "Coltsville National Historical Park" in the State is subject to conditions including a written agreement with the State, city, or public entity for land management within the historic district and ensuring financial resources of property owners within the park boundary. The proposed Coltsville National Historical Park will include key sites like the East Armory, Church of the Good Shepherd, and Colt Park. The Secretary will collaborate with state entities to access Colt-related artifacts for display in the park. The administration of the proposed Coltsville National Historical Park will involve collaboration with state entities to access Colt-related artifacts for display. The Secretary will administer the park in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Organic Act and the Act of August 21, 1935. State and local jurisdictions retain authority over civil and criminal matters within the park boundaries. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements as needed to implement the Act. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with property owners in the Coltsville Historic District or nationally significant properties within the park boundaries to identify, interpret, restore, and provide technical assistance for property preservation. The agreements grant the Secretary access to public areas for conducting tours and interpreting the properties for the public. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements with property owners in historic districts or significant park properties to interpret, restore, and provide technical assistance for preservation. No changes can be made without agreement, and any misuse may require reimbursement to the United States. The Secretary can acquire land and require matching funds for federal funds received under cooperative agreements. The non-Federal share can be in the form of donated property, goods, or services. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land and interests in land by donation, purchase, or exchange. Technical assistance and public interpretation of historic and cultural resources within the district are also allowed. The management plan for the district includes acquiring land, providing technical assistance, and interpreting historic and cultural resources. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, must complete a management plan for the park within 3 fiscal years, including cost-sharing provisions for necessary improvements and operations. The plan will be submitted to the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives. The management plan for the park must be completed within 3 fiscal years, with cost-sharing provisions for improvements and operations. It will be submitted to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate. SEC. 6. COLTSVILLE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK ADVISORY COMMISSION. Establishment of the Coltsville National Historical Park Advisory Commission to advise the Secretary in developing and implementing the management plan. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including members recommended by the Governor, State Senate President, and Speaker of the State House of Representatives. The Coltsville National Historical Park Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, with specific appointment criteria including recommendations from the Mayor of Hartford, Connecticut, Connecticut's United States Senators, and Connecticut's First Congressional District Representative. Additionally, members must have experience with national parks and historic preservation, significant knowledge of the Coltsville Historic District, and one member must reside in the Sheldon/Charter Oak neighborhood within Coltsville. The Coltsville National Historical Park Advisory Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, with specific appointment criteria including recommendations from the Mayor of Hartford, Connecticut, Connecticut's United States Senators, and Connecticut's First Congressional District Representative. Members are appointed for a 3-year term, with the possibility of one reappointment. Vacancies on the Commission are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Coltsville National Historical Park Advisory Commission appoints members for a 3-year term, with the possibility of one reappointment. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission meets at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members, with a majority constituting a quorum. A Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are selected from among the members, serving for a maximum of 1 year each without compensation. Members of the Coltsville National Historical Park Advisory Commission are allowed travel expenses and staff support as needed to carry out their duties. The Secretary may accept personnel detailed from the State or any political subdivision. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission will terminate 10 years after the enactment of the Act unless extended by recommendation to the Secretary. The Commission may be extended for up to 10 years by the Secretary if deemed necessary.
